Can we reword this.. 
This commit implements the PortCollection collection schema.
PortCollection is a child of the FabricAdapters schema. One use case of Ports is the inventory properties such as serial number, part number, etc.
Done
basic properties of PortCollection ?

The current submission only implements the basic properties of
PortCollection (Id, Name, etc.) The Port implementation and implementation of Port properties such as Serial Number, etc., will follow in later commits
Done
Done

looks like you are using some custom wrapping, please use 50/72
See https://cbea.ms/git-commit/
Done
Please mark this as WIP until these commits are available.  Returning an always empty collection is not useful, and I'm not interesting in maintaining code that's not useful.

> Please mark this as WIP until these commits are available.  Returning an always empty collection is not useful, and I'm not interesting in maintaining code that's not useful.

ready for review
This is not an effective test if it only ever returns 0

> This is not an effective test if it only ever returns 0

removed in this one
Commit message is updated in pathset#10
Happy to see progress, please mark patches WIP if they're not in a useful state.
Sure, Thanks
Commit doesn't do a lot but seems reasonable
All adapters have ports?  That doesn't seem right.

In case there is no Ports, the link will show the 0 Members.
Would it be acceptable?

```
$ curl -k -X GET https://${bmc}/redfish/v1/Systems/system/FabricAdapters/pcie_card0
{
....
  "Ports": {
    "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/Systems/system/FabricAdapters/pcie_card0/Ports"
  },
...
}

curl -k -X GET https://${bmc}/redfish/v1/Systems/system/FabricAdapters/pcie_card0/Ports
{
  "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/Systems/system/FabricAdapters/pcie_card0/Ports",
  "@odata.type": "#PortCollection.PortCollection",
  "Members": [],
  "Members@odata.count": 0,            <== 0 members
  "Name": "Port Collection"
}%
```

Or, should we check the existence of ports first and then disable this "Ports" link?

Showing an empty Members array / a Members@odata.count of 0 is what we do other places. There was a email on the list about this ("Re: [Help Required]Unsupported routes and properties present on Redfish Interface") but haven't seen any more discussion after I replied to the initial email. Until/If we change direction, I feel the current patch is reasonable in this regard.

Sorry, I haven't mentioned.

I made the change to detect the the existence of Ports.
The new update should show it only when Ports exists.
I don't see array used here. I guess it is in the commit above. It would be best if it was in that commit. Same with functional.

> I don't see array used here. I guess it is in the commit above. It would be best if it was in that commit. Same with functional.

Oops, I forgot remove this.
Done

> Don't you need checks for 
>    if (systemName != "system")
>     {
> 
> above ?

check L: 60
https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/redfish-core/lib/fabric_adapters.hpp#L215
Done
I see no required Members property here.  Unclear how the validator passes.
Ack
This p
This doesn't return anything but static data?
It is fixed by pathset#10.
This isn't needed.  Because we're looking these up by association, there's no need to check if the adapter exists.  The assocation wont exist if the adapter doesn't exist.
Updated in pathset#11

In fact, the check is needed to filter out the invalid fabric adapter.

```
curl -k https://${bmc}/redfish/v1/Systems/system/FabricAdapters/bad-fabric-adapter-id/Ports
```

Without it, it will not return an error msg but show 0 member collection.
> Updated in pathset#11

Another comment.

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/61374 would be needed to make port schema working.

For example, "/redfish/v1/Systems/<str>/FabricAdapters/<str>/Ports/<str>/"

Can you add how it is determined the Ports belong to the Fabric Adapters? It looks like we look at the path.. I don't think that matches with how we have been doing inventory to inventory links (instead using an associations in other designs (e.g. chassis to powersupply))

Updated code is based on the association between FabricAdapter and Ports.
It is defined by https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/62881

```

    dbus::utility::getAssociationEndPoints(
        fabricAdapterPath + "/connecting",
        [aResp, systemName,
         adapterId](const boost::system::error_code& ec,
                    const dbus::utility::MapperEndPoints& endpoints) {
        if (ec)
        ...
```

How does the validator pass if we put the Port out as a link without a implementation 

        item["@odata.id"] = crow::utility::urlFromPieces(
            "redfish", "v1", "Systems", systemName, "FabricAdapters", adapterId,
            "Ports", connectorId);

This code puts out the link, but the commit above has the ROUTE

    BMCWEB_ROUTE(app,
                 "/redfish/v1/Systems/<str>/FabricAdapters/<str>/Ports/<str>/")
        .privileges(redfish::privileges::getPort)

These have to merge together I assume? Can you state that ?

Right, I've tested with combined ones - https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/61374

I'll restate the commit message.
I've modified the commit msg stating the excluded/failed validator errors.

- Members
- Members@odata.count 

Like other collections?
Yes, the output is essentially the same like getCollectionMembers() but the output needs to insert "/Ports/.
why not portId?
Changed in the latest patchset.
Shouldn't we return resourceNotFound error? Is this an optional association?

The intention of this logic is to detect whether there are the associated ports for the given fabric adapter.
Not all fabric adapters are required to have the ports, and fabric adapter without ports are not treated as an error case.

If there are port(s), it will show like 
```
curl -k -X GET https://${bmc}:18080/redfish/v1/Systems/system/FabricAdapters/disk_backplane0
...
  "Ports": {
    "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/Systems/system/FabricAdapters/disk_backplane0/Ports"
  },
  ```
  
If not, the above output should not be shown.
what if the fabric adapter supports multiple ports?

This part is handling the query to fabric adapter, not the fabric adapter's Ports.
Here are the check is the existence of one or more ports.
If there are port(s), it will show the link, not the list of ports.

Instead of checking if the fabric adapter has ports, shouldn't we directly provide the link to the ports and have the port collection handle the task of listing the ports?  what is the reasoning behind the current approach of checking for port existence at this level? 
we don't have this kind of checking for other links ex: PCIeCard-> PCIeFunctions

I originally wrote it as always showing the link and then the link may give '0' members like in many places.

This change is to respond Ed's comment here.

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/61097/comment/8740b2e5_d8a49a52/
Allocate of Members and initialize of "Members@odata.count" to 0 before return otherwise validator will fail. May be initialize in doPortCollectionGet.

You're right.
For the safer & clearer approach, I'll initialize it in doPortCollectionGet().
Fixed in the next patchset.
You should include the reference of the related commit that needs to be submitted together for the validator to pass.

I think - an unresolved gerrit link is better not to be included but it should be okay to mentione that the validator will fail only with this commit.
(The commit message explains sufficiently the scope of this commit).

So, your suggestion may be better to combine together as one commit
(In fact, I'm also thinking about it).

You can just comment out the URL should work
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/61097/28/redfish-core/lib/port.hpp#47

That line is to goal of this commit to show the collection.
So, the line can't be commented out.

I do not think there is anything incorrect or wrong on the commit message as it accurately represent what this commit is doing.

Putting the future unresolved gerrit link may be even incorrect as the future change id could be changed or may be decides not be done in the future.  Then this commit message becomes incorrect.
So, referring anything which is not already done is not correct.

Anyway, I just combined 2 commits into one.

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/61374 is combined into this commit,
and 61374 will be abandoned.

Usually we add a check to ensure that only non-empty portId values are added to the portIdNames. Currently, if sdbusplus::message::object_path(path).filename() returns an empty string, the portId variable will also be assigned an empty string, leading to an invalid URL for that port.
Done
Redundancy in initializing the members array. The members array is initially set to an empty array in the doHandlePortCollectionGet function.
Done
Name should be "Port"

This is not a collection of Ports, but a base 'port' resource schema - which should have "Name" & "Id".

```
curl -k -X GET https://${bmc}:18080/redfish/v1/Systems/system/FabricAdapters/disk_backplane0/Ports/dp0_port1
    {
      "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/Systems/system/FabricAdapters/disk_backplane0/Ports/dp0_port1",
      "@odata.type": "#Port.v1_7_0.Port",
      "Id": "dp0_port1",
      "Name": "dp0_port1"    <-----
    }%
```
Log portId

bmcweb does not handle this 'not found' cases consistently.
Another example like this is
https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/redfish-core/lib/pcie.hpp#L74

Anyway, it may be good to add the portId into log
split into a new function using std::bind_front.

Not sure it is necessary here.

This code has 2 simple inner calls with lambdas - which are more readable than going thru 2 separate functions via bind_front.

Even if we prefer to use bind_front(), in this case a small lamdba still be needed to pass the arguments properly.
So I don't think this is a good example case to use bind_front().
I've refactored to reduce the depth of lambdas by using std::bind_front().
I thought that you would add more code in future commits, so it would be beneficial to consider refactoring.
I've done in the patchset 32
nit: Why does only this function have prolog comments, while the rest of the file lacks them? Should consider removing the prolog here?
It was inherited from the previous code.  Yes, I'll remove it.
